docs.snippet: There is something new for the spice rack: scarlet, sand-textured powder from sun-dried tomatoes. Sprinkle it on a sandwich or on pasta or risotto, or add it on fish for a touch of intense tomato flavor. The powder is $10 for a 2.6-ounce jar, but ...
docs.abstract: New spice called scarlet is sand-textured powder from sun-dried tomatoes; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: There is something new for the spice rack: scarlet, sand-textured powder from sun-dried tomatoes. Sprinkle it on a sandwich or on pasta or risotto, or add it on fish for a touch of intense tomato flavor. The powder is $10 for a 2.6-ounce jar, but a little goes a long way. It is available at Oliviers & Company stores in Grand Central Terminal, at 249 Bleecker Street (Seventh Avenue South) and at 198 Columbus Avenue (69th Street).

docs.snippet: A small group of students sip wine as they gather around their instructor, Paul Vandewoude, in the kitchen of the Miette Culinary Studio, which specializes in cooking classes for no more than 10 students at a time. Mr. Vandewoude, formerly the che...
docs.abstract: Paul Vandewoude gives cooking lessons at Miette Culinary Studio, Greenwich Village, in classes for no more than 10 students at time; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A small group of students sip wine as they gather around their instructor, Paul Vandewoude, in the kitchen of the Miette Culinary Studio, which specializes in cooking classes for no more than 10 students at a time. Mr. Vandewoude, formerly the chef at two Greenwich Village cafes, Tartine and Titou, teaches them how to roast lamb or chicken, make paella and bake chocolate cake, among other dishes. What's especially nice is that the kitchen is well equipped with home appliances, not those found only in restaurants. Children's classes are also given. Mariette Bermowitz, an owner, also rents the three-room studio, which has a separate pastry area in addition to the kitchen and a dining room, for events like group cooking parties and children's parties.

headline.main: Too Many Cooks Can Spoil the Lesson

docs.snippet: A clever package of chili peppers, in red, green, orange and yellow, makes up a primer of  heat. There are 8 to 10 of them in a small plastic box. It has a chart on the back, which serves as a guide to their fire, from the mildest skinny Dutch chi...
docs.abstract: Chili kits providing chili peppers of various heat are available at Agata & Valentina; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A clever package of chili peppers, in red, green, orange and yellow, makes up a primer of heat. There are 8 to 10 of them in a small plastic box. It has a chart on the back, which serves as a guide to their fire, from the mildest skinny Dutch chilies and Thai chilies to the hottest habaneros. Each of them will be milder if the seeds are discarded. It's a good idea to wear rubber or plastic gloves when cutting the chilies, or put plastic sandwich bags over your hands, because their oils can sting and should not come in contact with your eyes or hands. The chili kits are $1.99 at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), and $3.98 at Jerry & David's Red Horse Market, Montauk Highway, East Hampton, N.Y.

headline.main: Hot, Hotter and Hottest, All in One Package

docs.snippet: She had a look on her face that I recognized all too well. Pride and excitement veiled with anxiety.     It's the ''Oh, my God, a food writer is coming to dinner'' expression.    Mr. Latte and I were visiting his parents for the weekend. And his m...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser Food Diary column on home-cooked meal prepared by her boyfriend's mother, Elizabeth Latte; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: She had a look on her face that I recognized all too well. Pride and excitement veiled with anxiety. It's the ''Oh, my God, a food writer is coming to dinner'' expression. Mr. Latte and I were visiting his parents for the weekend. And his mother, Elizabeth, a woman with glittering eyes, a Katharine Hepburn voice and a sharp sense of humor, announced that she was cooking dinner.

docs.snippet: Bright, golden zucchini blossoms have made their debut at the Union Square Greenmarket. Ray Dare grows them in hothouses at his Cherry Lane Farm in Bridgeton, N.J. He expects to have them from the field in a week or two and throughout the summer. ...
docs.abstract: Bright, edible golden zucchini blossoms have made their debut at Union Square Greenmarket in Manhattan; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bright, golden zucchini blossoms have made their debut at the Union Square Greenmarket. Ray Dare grows them in hothouses at his Cherry Lane Farm in Bridgeton, N.J. He expects to have them from the field in a week or two and throughout the summer. The flowers, with or without a baby zucchini attached, are four for $1. Separate the flowers, dip them in a thin fritter batter (seasoned flour and water) and fry until golden. You can also stuff them about three-quarters full with diced mozzarella, herbs and bits of anchovy or capers, twist the tops of the petals closed, then batter and fry.

headline.main: Before Zucchini Season, Savor Its Blooms

docs.snippet: Chicken is on a pedestal in more ways than one in ''The Artful Chicken'' by Linda Arnaud (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95). There are mother hen milk-glass serving pieces, rooster-headed salt-and-pepper sets, chickens on weavings and rugs, ceramic...
docs.abstract: Comment on The Artful Chicken, book by Linda Arnaud; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Chicken is on a pedestal in more ways than one in ''The Artful Chicken'' by Linda Arnaud (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95). There are mother hen milk-glass serving pieces, rooster-headed salt-and-pepper sets, chickens on weavings and rugs, ceramic plates, posters, folk art and Fabergé eggs. The bird's role in history is explained, and illustrated with chickens on an ancient Greek vase and in a Roman fresco.

headline.main: All Praise The Chicken, A Delight To Both Eye And Mouth

docs.snippet: Delis and other food shops are suddenly offering custom-made salads assembled by a designated tosser from ingredients of the customer's choosing, or from a set menu. Perhaps they got the idea from Tossed, a salad spot with locations on Park Avenue...
docs.abstract: Delis and other food shops are suddenly offering custom-made salads assembled by designated tosser from ingredients of customer's choosing, or from set menu; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Delis and other food shops are suddenly offering custom-made salads assembled by a designated tosser from ingredients of the customer's choosing, or from a set menu. Perhaps they got the idea from Tossed, a salad spot with locations on Park Avenue South and at Rockefeller Center. Could the salad bar the size of a football field, with lunchtime crowds picking over the goods, be on its way out?

docs.snippet: A stunning new gazpacho, a silken palate-pleaser at the Brasserie, 100 East 53rd Street, looks like a bloody mary served in a martini glass. It even has enough spice to suggest the cocktail. Topped with mint cream, it hovers between sippable and s...
docs.abstract: Brasserie, Manhattan restaurant, offers gazpacho served in martini glass; recipe; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A stunning new gazpacho, a silken palate-pleaser at the Brasserie, 100 East 53rd Street, looks like a bloody mary served in a martini glass. It even has enough spice to suggest the cocktail. Topped with mint cream, it hovers between sippable and spoonable. The Brasserie's gazpacho is $8, but you can easily whip it up at home. I'd even consider spiking it with vodka or silver tequila for a summer brunch.

docs.snippet: For people on the go who don't want to buy bottled water, Brita, a company that makes charcoal filters for removing chlorine, odors and unpleasant flavors from water, has introduced a 20-ounce water bottle with a small carbon filter about the size...
docs.lead_paragraph: For people on the go who don't want to buy bottled water, Brita, a company that makes charcoal filters for removing chlorine, odors and unpleasant flavors from water, has introduced a 20-ounce water bottle with a small carbon filter about the size of a cigarette lighter in its cap. The plastic bottle has a blue push-pull cap and a spot to place a sticker to remind the user to replace the filter every hundred refills or so. The bottle is about $8 at housewares stores, and replacement filters are about $3.50.

headline.main: A Way for the Footloose To Filter Their Own Water

docs.snippet: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pista...
docs.lead_paragraph: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pistachios are arrayed in small containers on the bakery counter, where ice cream ($6 to $8 a portion), fruit tarts ($6), filled beignets ($6 for six) and layered coupes of cream, cake, jelly and mousse ($7 to $8) are assembled a la minute -- in two to four minutes -- while you wait. For the chef, Philippe Conticini, and the company's president, Armen Petrossian, freshness is paramount. The caramelized apple tart with riesling gelee is assembled and warmed just before serving, so that the crisp pastry shell does not become soggy. The vanilla ice cream is churned fresh, order by order. Classic French pastries like gat eau St.-Honore must be ordered in advance.

headline.main: Pastries Built on the Spot, Ice Cream Mixed to Order and, of Course, Caviar
